metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of magma-metamorphic rocks in the Lhagoi Kangri dome, Himalayan orogen
metadata.description: This data set includes whole-rock major trace and isotopic geochemical data, monazite, and zircon radioisotope dating data. The samples were collected from the Laguigangri dome of the Himalayan orogenic belt in southern Tibet. The geochemical data of major elements in the whole rock are obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, the trace elements are obtained by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer, and the radioisotope dating of monazite and zircon is obtained by laser denudation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer. The data quality is high. These data show that the leucogranitic magma in the Himalayan orogenic belt was formed in multiple stages and came from different homologous areas, which provides a key limit for the magmatic formation mechanism.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in Excel format. The document name is "wrmajtriso", which represents the main trace elements and isotopes of the whole rock; The file name is "monage", representing monazite age data, and the file name is "zrnage", representing zircon age data

authorList.unitEn: Institute of Geology and Geophysics, Chinese Academy of Scienes

literatureList.titleEn: Multistage magmatism recorded in a single gneiss dome: Insights from the Lhagoi Kangri leucogranites, Himalayan orogen
literatureList.referenceEn: He, S.X., Liu, X.C., Yang L., Wang, J.M., Hu,F.Y., & Wu, F.Y. (2021). Multistage magmatism recorded in a single gneiss dome: Insights from the Lhagoi Kangri leucogranites, Himalayan orogen. Lithos. 398-399, 106222.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of geochemical datasets related to magmatic-metamorphic rocks in the Himalayan orogenic belt?
Feature Specification.Answer: whole-rock major and trace elements, isotopic geochemistry data, radiometric dating of monazite and zircon, high data quality, major elements analyzed using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, trace elements analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, radiometric dating conducted using laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

Quantification.Question: How many samples were collected from the Lhagoi Kangri dome in the Himalayan orogen for geochemical analysis?
Quantification.Answer: The data does not specify the exact number of samples collected from the Lhagoi Kangri dome.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be inferred about the formation stages and source areas of granitic magmas in the Himalayan orogeny based on geochemical and isotopic patterns observed in collected samples?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical and isotopic data collected from the Lhagoi Kangri dome in the southern Tibetan Himalaya indicate that the leucogranitic magmas formed in multiple stages and originated from different source areas. This suggests a complex magmatic formation mechanism in the Himalayan orogeny.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the high quality of geochemical data collected from the Himalaya orogeny Lhagoi Kangri dome in southern Tibet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high quality of geochemical data is attributed to the use of advanced analytical techniques: whole-rock major element geochemistry data is obtained through X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, trace elements are analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and monazite and zircon radiogenic isotope dating is conducted using laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. These methods ensure accurate and reliable data, providing crucial insights into the formation stages and diverse source regions of leucogranite magmas in the Himalaya orogeny.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting geochemical and isotopic data from the magmatic-metamorphic rocks in the Lhagoi Kangri dome of the southern Tibet Himalaya orogeny?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to understand the formation mechanisms of leucogranitic magmas in the Himalaya orogeny, determine the stages and source regions of magma formation, and provide critical constraints on the geochemical processes involved.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental techniques are employed to ensure high-quality geochemical and isotopic data collection from rock samples in the Himalayan orogenic belt, and how do these techniques contribute to understanding the formation stages of leucogranite magmas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the Himalayan orogenic belt, geochemical data collection from rock samples involves using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometry for major element analysis, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for trace elements, and laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) for radiogenic isotope dating of monazite and zircon. These techniques provide high-quality data that reveal leucogranite magmas formed in multiple stages from different sources, offering critical insights into the magmatic formation mechanisms.
